text: hello I'm dr. Kyle Kinmen from certified
Foot & Ankle specialists here to talk to
you today about peripheral neuropathy
and how we can usually reverse those
symptoms with nerve decompression
procedures it's a common misconception
among the medical community and the lake
community that peripheral neuropathy is
permanent and so people are very upset
when they hear that peripheral
neuropathy pain is going to be with them
forever and they're often treated by
narcotic medication anti-seizure
medication antidepressants injections
all types of different modalities that
usually fail and the pain from
neuropathy can be debilitating patients
also suffer keeps them up at night have
trouble sleeping but fortunately despite
the misconception there are procedures
in the lower extremity that we can do
that will reverse the symptoms and the
pain of peripheral neuropathy ninety
percent of the time in the appropriate
patient this includes diabetic
peripheral neuropathy chemotherapy
induced neuropathy and other types of
neuropathy usually the diagnosis is made
and the confirmation that the patient is
a candidate for procedure is made with a
physical exam we can also confirm that
further sometimes with nerve conduction
studies but most of it we can tell on
initial evaluation with physical exam
and then assuming the patient is healthy
and able to undergo the procedure it's
an outpatient procedure that's done in a
surgery center takes about 45 minutes
there are three or four incisions and
the patient has stitches in place for
two weeks postoperatively and usually
the pain from the neuropathy is gone
when they wake up and if they've had
numbness associated with the neuropathy
they're very happy to see that they can
again feel their feet in the recovery
room it happens that quickly and so it's
a very rewarding procedure so if you
have
peripheral neuropathy or someone you
know suffers from peripheral neuropathy
please come see us at certified foot and
ankle and we'd love to do this procedure
if you're a candidate and help to
relieve your pain
[Music]
you
